case_name: University of Mysore and Anniah Gowda v. C.D. Govinda Rao

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 417 and 418 of 1963 were filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 7, 1962, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1197 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 417 and 418 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 7, 1962, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1197 of 1960.

facts.text: The respondent C.D. Govinda Rao filed a writ petition in Mysore High Court under Article 226 praying for quo warranto against Anniah Gowda holding post of Research Reader in English at Central College, Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: The petition from which these appeals by special leave arise was filed by the respondent, C.D. Govinda Rao, in the Mysore High Court under art. 226 of the Constitution. By that petition, he prayed that a writ of quo warranto be issued, calling upon Anniah Gowda to show cause as to under what authority he was holding the post of a Research Reader in English in the Central College, Bangalore.

facts.text: Respondent prayed for writ of mandamus directing University of Mysore to appoint him as Research Reader in scale Rs. 500-25-800.

anchor.surface_text: He also prayed for a writ of mandamus or other appropriate writ or direction calling upon the University of Mysore to appoint him Research Reader in the scale of Rs. 500-25-800. His case was that the appointment of Anniah Gowda to the post of Research Reader was illegal in the face of the prescribed qualifications and that he was qualified to be appointed to that post.

facts.text: University of Mysore and Anniah Gowda disputed the validity of respondent's claim and argued Anniah Gowda was properly appointed.

anchor.surface_text: The University of Mysore and Anniah Gowda disputed the validity of the claim made by the respondent. lie, urged that Anniah Gowda was properly appointed Research Reader and that the companytention made by the respondent that the said appointment was invalid was number justified.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held appointment of Anniah Gowda invalid, quashed the resolution of Board of Appointments and directed setting aside of Chancellor's appointment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that the appointment of Anniah Gowda was invalid and so it has quashed the Resolution of the Board of Appointment of the University of Mysore recommending his appointment and his directed that his appointment subsequendy made by the Chancellor of the University should be set aside.

facts.text: High Court refused mandamus for respondent's appointment, stating it does not necessarily follow.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, refrained from granting the respondent a writ of mandamus, directing his appointment to the said if the appointment post, because it took the view that even of Anniah Gowda was set aside, it did number follow that the respondent would necessarily be entitled to that post.

facts.text: University and Anniah Gowda applied for certificate to appeal to Supreme Court, rejected, then obtained special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The University and Anniah Gowda, then, moved the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court against its judgement, but the application was rejected. Thereupon the University and Anniah Gowda by separate applications moved this Court for special leave, and on special leave being granted to them, they have brought the two present appeals before us.

facts.text: University of Mysore published advertisement on 31st July 1959 for posts including Professor and Reader in English.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on 31st July 1959, appellant No. 1 published an advertisement calling for applications for sit posts of Professors and six posts of Readers. Amongst them were included the post of Professor of English and the Reader in English.

facts.text: Qualifications prescribed: First or High Second Class Masters Degree... Ordinarily ten years... experience... Knowledge of Kannada desirable.

anchor.surface_text: The qualifications prescribed for these posts are material and it is companyvenient to set them out at this stage Qualifications A First or High Second Class Masters Degree of an Indian University or an equivalent qualification of a Foreign University in the subject companycerned A Research Degree of a Doctorate Standard or published work of a high Standard Ordinarily, ten years  number less than five years in any case  experience of teaching post-graduate classes...

facts.text: Board of Appointments constituted under s.26(2) Mysore University Act 1956: Vice-Chancellor, Prof P.E. Dastoor (Delhi), Prof L.D. Murphy (Madras).

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with s. 26 2  of the Mysore University Act, 1956  No. 23 of 1956 , as it then stood, a Board of Appointments was numberinated, companyysiting of the Vice-Chan- cellor and two Specialists in English. These Specialists were Professor P. E. Dastoor of the Delhi University and Professor L. D. Murphy of Madras.

facts.text: Four applications received for Professor and Reader in English, interviewed on June 8, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Four applications were received for the posts of Professors and Reader in English and these Applicants were interviewed by the Board on June 8, 1960.

facts.text: Board consulted Prof C.D. Narasimhiah, Principal Maharajas College, Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The Board had the advantage of companyysulting Professor C.D. Narasimhiah, Principal, Maharajas College, Mysore.

facts.text: Board resolved no applicant fit for Professor post, kept vacant; unanimously recommended Anniah Gowda (appellant 2) for Reader post.

anchor.surface_text: After taking into account the opinion expressed by Prof. Narasimhiah, the Board companyysidered the academic qualifications of the four applicants and their performance at the interview and came to the companyclusion that numbere of them was fit enough to be appointed a Professor... Accordingly, the Board resolved that the said posts be kept vacant... the Board... unanimously resolved that he be appointed Reader in the said grade under the U.G.C. Scheme.

facts.text: Board's report approved by Chancellor on October 3, 1960; Anniah Gowda assumed charge on October 31, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: This report was in due companyrse approved by the Chancellor on October 3, 1960, and after he was appointed to the post of Reader, appellant No. 2 assumed charge on October 31, 1960.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition on October 15, 1960, initially sought injunction, modified to quo warranto after appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, even before he assumed charge of his office, the respondent had filed his present petition on October 15, 1960, and he had claimed an injunction against appellant No. 1 from proceeding to fill the post, but since the post had already been filled up, he modified his claim and asked for a writ of quo warranto against appellant No. 2.

facts.text: Anniah Gowda secured 50.2 per cent marks in his Masters Degree examination.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that appellant No. 2 secured 50.2 per cent marks in his Masters Degree examination.

facts.text: Anniah Gowda obtained Master of Arts Degree from University of Durham.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the second qualification, it appears that appellant No. 2 has obtained a Degree of Master of Arts of the University of Durham.

facts.text: High Court held Anniah Gowda did not satisfy first qualification (high second class Masters).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has upheld this plea. In regard to the second qualification... The High Court has held that... it would number be Just for the Court to differ...

facts.text: Supreme Court held that MA from Durham University is equivalent to high second class Masters of Indian University, satisfying first qualification.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that Masters Degree of the Durham University which appellant No. 2 has obtained, can be and must have been taken by the Board to be equivalent to a high Second Class Masters Degree of an Indian University, and that means the first qualification is satisfied by appellant No. 2.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeals, set aside High Court judgment quashing appointment of Anniah Gowda.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals are allowed, the.

facts.text: Posts advertised pursuant to grant by University Grants Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The posts of Professor and Reader had been advertised in pursuance of a grant made to appellant No. 1 by the University Grants Commission.

facts.text: Respondent claimed Anniah Gowda lacked 5 years teaching degree classes experience.

anchor.surface_text: Evidence was led by both the parties and the respondent seriously disputed the claim made by both the appellants that appellant No. 2 satisfied the test of five years experience of teaching Degree classes.

facts.text: High Court found material on teaching experience unsatisfactory but could not find for respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court examined this evidence and ultimately came to the companyclusion that though the material adduced by the appellants on this point was unsatisfactory, it companyld number make a finding in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court noted Anniah Gowda has published works satisfying second qualification.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it appears that appellant No. 2 has to his credit published works which by themselves would satisfy the second qualification.

facts.text: Affidavit by Anniah Gowda on July 22, 1961 detailed teaching experience exceeding 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: On the question about the length of the teaching career of appellant No. 2, appellant No. 2 had made a detailed affidavit on July 22, 1961. In this affidavit, he had set out the several teaching assignments he had held and the periods during which he held them, and these clearly show that his teaching experience of the prescribed character is much more than five years...

Mysore High Court under art. 226 of the Constitution. By that petition, he prayed that a writ of quo warranto be issued, calling upon Anniah Gowda to show cause as to under what authority he was holding the post

issues.text: Whether the appointment of Anniah Gowda (Appellant No. 2) to the post of Research Reader in English was valid, particularly in light of the prescribed qualifications

anchor.surface_text: That is how the main dispute which arose between the two appellants and the respondent was in regard to the validity of the appointment of appellant No. 2 to the post of Reader in English, and as we have already pointed out, the High Court upheld the contentions of the respondent and quashed the appointment of appellant No. 2.

arguments.claim: Appointment of Anniah Gowda is illegal because he did not secure a high Second Class Masters Degree (50.2% marks not sufficient for high second class)

anchor.surface_text: It appears that appellant No. 2 secured 50.2 per cent marks in his Masters Degree examination. It was urged by the respondent before the High Court that when 50 per cent is the minimum required for securing a second class, it would be idle to suggest that a candidate, who obtains 50.2 per cent, has secured a high Second Class Masters Degree, and so the respondent pleaded that the first condition had not been satisfied by the appellant No. 2.

holdings.text: the High Court was in error in issuing a writ of quo warranto, quashing the appointment of appellant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we must hold that the High Court was in error in issuing a writ of quo warranto, quashing the appointment of appellant No. 2.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Anniah Gowda satisfied qualifications; High Court erred on first qualification by ignoring foreign equivalence and expert opinion.

holdings.text: courts should be slow to interfere with the opinions expressed by the experts... it would normally be wise and safe for the courts to leave the decisions of academic matters to experts who are more familiar with the problems they face than the courts generally can be.

anchor.surface_text: Boards of Appointments are nominated by the Universities and when recommendations made by them and the appointments following on them, are challenged before courts, normally the courts should be slow to interfere with the opinions expressed by the experts. There is no allegation about mala fides against the experts who constituted the present Board and so, we think, it would normally be wise and safe for the courts to leave the decisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expert boards better placed on academic qualifications; no allegation of mala fides; Board carefully considered candidates and rejected for higher post.

holdings.text: it would not be open to the respondent to take a ground about the effect of the statutory rules and ordinances for the first time in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment delivered by the High Court in the present proceedings is an elaborate judgment and we think it would be legitimate to assume that it does not refer to the statutory rules and ordinances for the simple reason that neither party relied on them and the. High Court had, therefore no occasion to examine them. In any case, we do not think it would be open to the respondent to take a ground about the effect of the statutory rules and ordi- nances for the first time in appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Argument not urged before High Court; no evidence ordinances in force at time of appointment; affidavits focused on advertised qualifications.

holdings.text: the error in this case is undoubtedly a manifest error. That is a consideration which is more germane and relevant in a procedure for a writ of certiorari.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court applied certiorari standard of manifest error inappropriate for quo warranto; should have checked contravention of law with regard to expert opinion.

holdings.text: the criticism made by the High Court against the Board and its deliberations is not justified.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the criticism made by the High Court against the Board and its deliberations is not justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board carefully examined applicants, rejected all for Professor post showing application of mind.

holdings.text: the harsh criticism made by the High Court against appellant No. 1 is not fully justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Minor inaccuracy in affidavit explanation; experience established by untraversed affidavit and registers; no intent to mislead.

Article 226 provides High Court power to issue writs addressing issues of appointment validity based on qualifications.

Section 42(5) specifies that ordinances come into force from the date directed by the Chancellor, which undercuts the argument's claim of contravention given the noted lack of evidence that the ordinances were in force at the relevant time.
